I want to find multiple files and replace all instances of a string inside them
will that command do such a thing?
right, so change your command to: grep -lr "search" ./ | xargs -I filename sed -i 's/search/replace/g' filename
say I'm starting a program from CLI like nautilus and I'm doing nautilus /path/to/directory &, it still outputs things to the terminal, how to prevent that?

you could use nohup and then output would go to a file nohup creates (and you'd have the added benefit of not having nautilus close when you close your terminal), or you could append 2>&1 > /dev/null  to your command
